Five rounds of shipping around cubes, strange take-it-or-leave-it commerce, last round killing frenzy where victory was stolen from the veteran player and the richest player won. This game just felt way too long and the pacing is completely off. First 3 turns you are trading and then everything starts to be locked up and once that happens people start looking for fights, which means the hard trades are just not going to happen and you'll just be spending the money you made early to keep up a warfleet. Then it really is just a messy wack-a-mole back and forth that can really just come down to player order, something that is set from the beginning and you can't really do much about.

Falls into this weird nothing space where it isn't a good tight modern euro, or an interesting conflict simulation either. It is an interesting idea and you could make something interesting out of this. If you want to keep up yours points you should be able to maintain trade, if there is no trade going on for 6 turns those cities should no longer gif max vp. Everyone should be poor, but once a city is rich it will always be rich, even if there are 5 or 6 fights that all make it change hands. The combat is also extremely unsatisfying.

It's cool that this is one of the first euro wargames, but I feel it really shows it's age.

I liked the 2nd edition, but this is much more wild. Less euro, fewer weird phases of getting income. And all those rules I forgot from 2nd edition, like churches, were just to score extra VP. Everything was just a VP engine. Here, they're simple motivations for how players negotiate with each other. Like your capital is worth nothing if you don't fill it up, so that's obviously on everyone's checklist. The end result is I feel a lot more tension, wondering if I'm going to cooperate or conflict with another player, and nothing in the game is restricting us. So we have to talk it out, and hopefully not drag both of us below another neutral player.

Now remembering a ton of wargames that are way more scripted and euro than this, with special event decks. But also scripted euro games that never allow for conflict. At least in this game, there's an arc of players peacefully trading, and then later competing and declaring war when they've maxed out the local region. It felt more educational than both genres, haha.

One thing that baffles me in 2nd edition is that clock that never changes. I guess it was to avoid bidding for turn order, but the end result is that everyone wanted consecutive spaces to move everything at once, so it didn't achieve anything. So that's my impression, how they added in more clunky rules to make it less freeform.

I actually like this game a lot, is definitely one of my favorites. It's nice and pretty challenging. Requires a lot of strategic thinking. It's also quite a lot about interaction between the players. Can get really long (3-4 hours for us).
